instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 1.3v @ J7000 pin 3
threads.message: I get 1.3v @ pin 3 of J7000 when plugging in the magsafe charger. I have tried injecting voltage of 5v at the pin 3, and <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> appears to get hot from the thermal camera, but I have swapped this out now 3 times from donor boards. I cannot imagine all 3 (<TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>'s) were bad. Is there something I am missing here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 1.3v @ J7000 pin 3
threads.message:
Did you find short there, to inject voltage?
When in doubt, ask before doing something that can damage more the board.

Post diode mode to ground at L7520; w/ and w/o J7000 connected.

Do you get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>?
What about <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 1.3v @ J7000 pin 3
threads.message:
I did have 0 volts at one point (J7000 pin 3), but after replacing a few parts, I just measured pin 3 again on j7000, and now it is at 1.973v with magsafe plugged in. I am not finding a short at all, just that voltage drop on the 3rd pin for j7000
1.9mv @ <CAPACITOR>C1206</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> with magsafe plugged in. J7000, pins 1 and 2 with magsafe plugged in is 14.97v. 
When you say "Post diode mode to ground at L7520; w/ and w/o J7000 connected." Are you telling me to remove the remove the mini board? I had purchased a new mini board because the prior one I did have, did indeed have a short. When I replaced the mini board, the short went away. 
L7520 is .454v in diode mode with mini board disconnected from J7000, then with the mini board plugged in to J7000 it reads .449v in diode mode (magsafe not plugged in).
3.405v with <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> @ <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> pin 13.
8.57v with magsafe plugged in to <RESISTOR>R3080</RESISTOR> pin 1 for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
.423v @ <CAPACITOR>C3540</CAPACITOR> pin 1 for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> with magsafe plugged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 1.3v @ J7000 pin 3
threads.message:
Be sure to have proper LIO board for your model!

Take care, 0V at a power rail doesn't mean to have short.
Did you even check if <SIGNAL>5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> power rail was enabled?
Check <RESISTOR>R8175</RESISTOR> voltage.
